name: 2017_10_humanities_student_major_572_personalfinance
title: 2017-10-humanities-student-major_572_personalfinance.txt
content_scrubbed:
If you're worried about the cost of a college degree, you could always go to a community or technical college and get a two year degree. If your area is anything like mine (also mid-sized midwestern city), the cost of a two year degree from a technical college is something like $10k-$15k in total, books included. 

There are plenty of lucrative trades or fields to pursue with a two year degree, and many of these technical colleges have great ties with businesses in the community. I'm currently attending such a school and love it; they're much more flexible with my schedule as far as online offerings go and are more focused on the application of knowledge rather than theory (as many liberal_arts universities are).

Or if school isn't your thing, invest it or put a large sum up for a down payment on a house. However, I do highly recommend at least a two year degree as the return on investment (especially factoring in cost) is usually very high.

EDIT: Also, for reference, I am also 26. One thing I found out when I was no longer considered a "dependent" for financial aid purposes was I became eligible for many more grants that I had previously been ineligible for (I received quite a bit more from grants as I got older). Technical and community colleges love returning adults or students a little older than your average college freshman. YMMV though depending on school and other aid offerings for your state (I'm in WI). I hope this helps; I'd be willing to discuss my specific situation in more depth if you'd like.
